properties.entry:
Arguments:

script=alias
The alias of the file-node that contains the XSL script. The script argument is mandatory.
tags=tag1,tag2[att1|att2+att3=value1+att4!=value2+!att5...|...],...

The optional tags argument allows to restrict the XHTML elements to which the XSL script is applied. If no tags argument is given, then the XSL script is applied to all elements.

The value of the tags argument has to be a comma separated list of element expressions. Note that space is used as argument separator. Therefore, no space is allowed within the list of element expressions. An element expression is an element name, optionally followed by an attributes expression in square brackets. An attributes expression is one or more attribute conditions concatenated by the + or | operators. The + operator has the meaning of logical "and", whereas the | operator has the meaning of logical "or". Note that explicit grouping of attribute conditions by round brackets is not supported, though grouping of conditions is done implicitly as the + operator has higher precedence than the | operator.

Check attribute existance
If an attribute condition consists solely of the attribute name, then the condition results to true, only if the element has an attribute with the given name. If the attribute name is preceded by an exclamation mark (!), then the attribute condition results to true if the element has no attribute with the given name. In other words, the exclamation mark has the meaning of logical "not".

Value comparison
The attribute name can be followed by the = or != operator, followed by a string constant. The = operator has the meaning of "equals" and the != operator has the meaning of "equals not". See the example below.

Character escapes
Whitespace is not allowed within the tags argument. Furthermore, the characters + and |, as well as comma (,) cannot be used within the value definition of an attribute comparison, because these characters are interpreted as operators and expression separators. To insert these characters in a value definition, the Unicode escape sequence \unnnn can be used, where nnnn is a decimal Unicode number.

factory=classname
The fully qualified factory class name that provides implementation of javax.xml.transform.TransformerFactory. This argument is optional. If no class name is provided, then the static method javax.xml.transform.TransformerFactory.newInstance() is used to create the factory object.

Description:
Applies the XSL script that is specified by the script argument to the content elements specified by the tags argument. If no tags argument is given, then the XSL script is applied to all XHTML elements in the content.

Note that the tags argument only allows basic value comparison for element selection. However, the XSL script allows further control on which XSL template is to be applied to which elements through the template matching mechanism. This allows element selection through XPATH expressions.

Example 1:

  script=my_xsl_script tags=span,div[id+title|class=note]

Given the argument definition above, the XSL script with alias my_xsl_script is applied to all span elements and to div elements that have an id attribute in combination with a title attribute or a class attribute with value "note".

Example 2:

  script=my_xsl_script tags=table[!border|border!=0]

Given the argument definition above, the XSL script with alias my_xsl_script is applied to table elements that have no border attribute or which have a border attribute with a value other than "0".
